Title:
Antimicrobial and Antioxidant Activities of Extracts from
Endophytic Fungi Isolated from Carissa carandas
Keywords:
Antimicrobial activity, Antioxidant activity, Endophytic
fungi
Abstract:
This is the first report of endophytic fungi derived from
Carissa carandas. The aims of this research are evaluate the
antimicrobial and antioxidant activities of extracts from endophytic
fungi, identify the potential fungal isolate by phylogenetic analysis
and analyze the composition of the potential crude extract by GC-MS.
Endophytic fungi were isolated from healthy leaves of C. carandas. A
total of 109 fungal isolates were obtained from 900 segments. All fungal
isolates were identified based on their morphological characteristics.
Thirty-six fungal isolates were selected by their morphological
appearance on potato dextrose agar and cultured into potato dextrose
broth. Fungal endophytes were extracted with hexane, and ethyl acetate.
One hundred and eight extracts were tested for their antimicrobial and
antioxidant activities by using colorimetric broth microdilution and
DPPH free radical scavenging assays. The endophytic fungus Nigrospora
sp. TSU-EFHA009 (accession number MK033475) produced the best active
extracts. Broth ethyl acetate extract (CE) had the strongest activity
against Cryptococcus neoformans at MIC 4 and MFC 8 µg/mL. Moreover, the
antimicrobial activity was confirmed using scanning electron microscopy
(SEM). The morphology of target cells was damage. In addition, this
active extract had the highest antioxidant activity with inhibitory
concentration (IC50) value of 0.03 mg/mL. The potential extract was
detected the total phenolic content by using colorimetric method. It
contained total phenolic content as 41.20±0.40 mg GAE/g. The results
from this first study indicated that endophytic fungi from C. carandas
are good source of antimicrobial and antioxidant substances.
